photo.description: Looking into the reflecting pool at sunset. The Taj Mahal is a white marble mausoleum located in Agra, Uttar Pradesh, India. It was built by Mughal emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his third wife, Mumtaz Mahal. The Taj Mahal is widely recognized as "the jewel of Muslim art in India and one of the universally admired masterpieces of the world's heritage". Taj Mahal is regarded by many as the finest example of Mughal architecture, a style that combines elements from Persian, Ottoman Turkish and Indian architectural styles. In 1983, the Taj Mahal became a UNESCO World Heritage Site. While the white domed marble mausoleum is the most familiar component of the Taj Mahal, it is actually an integrated complex of structures. The construction began around 1632 and was completed around 1653, employing thousands of artisans and craftsmen. The construction of the Taj Mahal was entrusted to a board of architects under imperial supervision, including Abd ul-Karim Ma'mur Khan, Makramat Khan, and Ustad Ahmad Lahauri. Lahauri is generally considered to be the principal designer. - wikipedia
photo.tags: agra india tajmahal taj mughal mausoleum reflection water blue sunset
photo.title: Optical impossibilty of Taj Mahal

photo.title: Taj Mahal

photo.description: Truly, a modern wonder of the world, the very recognizable Taj Mahal (in Agra, Uttar Pradesh, India) is the legacy of man's love for his wife. In 1627, Shah Jahan became the 5th in the dynasty of Moghul Emperors to rule India. Befitting a man of his status and wealth, he married three wives. But his favorite was his queen, Arjumand Banu. She was crowned with the title Mumtaz Mahal or "Chosen One of the Palace." Shah Jahan so loved Mumtaz Mahal, that he pledged that he would forever honor her with the greatest monument ever seen by the world. But Shah Jahan never imagined that he would need to fulfill his promise so soon after their marriage. Mumtaz Mahal died giving birth to her fourteenth (...yes fourteenth) child at the tender age of 39.

photo.title: A Love Poem Written in Marble

photo.title: Minaret in the mist

photo.description: In 1631, Shah Jahan, emperor during the Mughal empire's period of greatest prosperity, was grief-stricken when his third wife, Mumtaz Mahal, died during the birth of their 14th child, Gauhara Begum. Construction of the Taj Mahal began in 1632. The court chronicles of Shah Jahan's grief illustrate the love story traditionally held as an inspiration for Taj Mahal. The principal mausoleum was completed in 1648 and the surrounding buildings and garden were finished five years later.
photo.title: View from the Mosque, Taj Mahal, Agra, India

photo.description: I've been resisting uploading this one for a while just because it is such a cliche, but each time I look at it it reminds me of getting up in the freezing cold, traveling through the streets of Agra in the dark by cycle rickshaw, and then entering the Taj Mahal complex, where the great mausoleum was emerging from the early morning mist. There were a few hundred people in the complex at this time in the morning, and the most striking thing was the silence- people were so awestruck they were not speaking. I guess it makes sense really- when you're presented with something as beautiful as this there are literally no words you can say that will not undermine it. My Most Interesting
photo.tags: tajmahal india agra earlymorning dawn mist glow purple beautiful grand eerie marble white cold texture monument mausoleum konicaminolta 5d angusmacrae asia fog cliche still silent sunrise

photo.description: The guide books say there are two ways to see the Taj and we made sure we did both. In the evening we went to the far bank of the Yamuna River and watched the sun go down. Anne extracted as much value as possible from the locals demanding money for photos. The following morning we got up way before dawn and made sure we were at the gates before they opened. By walking briskly we had the place to ourselves for a few minutes - magical. As we wandered out the crowds poured in. These pictures were taken as part of a trip to Delhi, Agra and eastern Rajasthan in March 2008.
photo.tags: tajmahal agra india
photo.title: The Taj - off centre for a change

photo.description: The Taj Mahal ( /ˈtɑːdʒ/ or /ˈtɑːʒ məˈhɑːl/; Hindi: ताज महल, from Persian/Urdu: تاج محل "crown of buildings", pronounced [ˈt̪aːdʒ mɛˈɦɛl]; also "the Taj") is a mausoleum located in Agra, India. It was built by Mughal emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his third wife, Mumtaz Mahal. The Taj Mahal is widely recognized as "the jewel of Muslim art in India and one of the universally admired masterpieces of the world's heritage." Taj Mahal is the finest example of Mughal architecture, a style that combines elements from Persian, Turkish and Indian architectural styles
photo.title: Taj Mahal, Agra, India

photo.description: Morning fog and mist gave me a blurry gaze of the city, and an ox-pulled cart passed through the souvenir stalls in front of the southern entrance of the Taj. The sky was clear, and the shadow fell just at the right angle. I wish I were a good photographer. Even the guarding entrances of the Taj astound me, resembling the majesty of the real Taj beyond the entrance. Security Check, no food allowed. Then I got into the inner court leading to the main gate of the Taj. The eastern entrance, just in front of the main gate, opened up to the Agra marketplace alleyways. Then I went through the main gate. The famous pond invited me to follow its flow to the Taj. I cannot describe the majesty of this building. Half of the Quran is written in stone carving all over the building. Geotagged Fly to this location (Requires Google Earth)
photo.tags: rani photography tajmahal agra india tree geo:lat=271747955 geo:lon=78042467 geotagged ge:tilt=0 2001 2001q1 byrani
photo.title: Taj Mahal Trees

Even the guarding entrances of the Taj astound me, resembling the majesty of the real Taj beyond the entrance. Security Check, no food allowed. Then I got into the inner court leading to the main gate of the Taj. The eastern entrance, just in front of the main gate, opened up to the Agra marketplace alleyways. photo.description: There were tons of people there this day. Some were tired of waiting in line and just hung out on the lawn in front of the beautiful building.

photo.description: You have to look pretty closely to notice all the little carvings that make up the dome in the large doorways. From far away they are too light to be seen, but if you get really close the light hints at all the tiny detail work around the building
photo.tags: india vacation agra tajmahal architecture
photo.title: Dome details

photo.description: You also have to love that they let you touch whatever you want and climb up on the building. If this was in the US you wouldn't be able to go up there, touch anything, or perhaps even take pictures. Yey for sensible people around the world!!!
photo.tags: india vacation agra tajmahal architecture
photo.title: Gotta love symmetry

photo.description: The Taj Mahal , is a mausoleum located in Agra, India, that was built under Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his favorite wife, Mumtaz Mahal. The Taj Mahal (also "the Taj") is considered the finest example of Mughal architecture, a style that combines elements from Persian, Turkish, Indian, and Islamic architectural styles. In 1983, the Taj Mahal became a UNESCO World Heritage Site and was cited as "the jewel of Muslim art in India and one of the universally admired masterpieces of the world's heritage." While the white domed marble and tile mausoleum is most familiar, Taj Mahal is an integrated symmetric complex of structures that was completed around 1648. Ustad Ahmad Lahauri is generally considered to be the principal designer of the Taj Maha Source :- en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taj_mahal

photo.description: In the distance is Agra Fort. (I'll put a link/note on a bit later when I upload those. Don't look to closely in the water. 20 minutes after a monsoon downpour the storm drains of the main town have emptied their contents into the river. Nice.
photo.tags: india september 2008 taj mahal agra canoneos400d geotagged golden triangle uttar pradesh
photo.title: Yamuna River

photo.description: Taj Mahal, Agra. Dedicated to Yol, who lost all her photos of the Taj Mahal on a train in India. All these photos are also yours.
photo.tags: agra hdr india marmol palacio tajmahal
photo.title: Taj

photo.description: The guide books say there are two ways to see the Taj and we made sure we did both. In the evening we went to the far bank of the Yamuna River and watched the sun go down. Anne extracted as much value as possible from the locals demanding money for photos. The following morning we got up way before dawn and made sure we were at the gates before they opened. By walking briskly we had the place to ourselves for a few minutes - magical. As we wandered out the crowds poured in. These pictures were taken as part of a trip to Delhi, Agra and eastern Rajasthan in March 2008.
photo.tags: tajmahal agra india sunrise orange dawn sun
photo.title: Dawn, all alone at the Taj

photo.description: No first trip to India would be complete without visiting the Taj Mahal. Overall, I initially thought it was pretty simple in design. However one I got closer and got a full grasp of the magnitude of the structure, I understood why this is the wonder of the world. 2009 World Trip: world.thelejo.com
photo.tags: taj mahal india white marble mausoleum agra persian indian islamic unesco wonder dome domed
photo.title: The Wonder

photo.description: This is the Yamuna river. On the left hand side, you can see the Agra Fort in some distance

photo.title: Keeping spirits up in the longest line ever

photo.description: Deze rit vergeet ik niet snel meer. Vlak voor het eind sprong ook een vriend/neef/partner/whatever van de chauffeur in de auto. Hij ging een rondleiding geven. Ik geloof niet dat we inspraak hadden. Maakt niet uit. Go with the flow, hier in India. Anders heb je geen leuke vakantie.
photo.tags: india agra tajmahal taj mahal
photo.title: Ingang Taj Mahal

photo.description: The day after we did our sightseeing in New Delhi, we went to Agra to see the Taj Mahal and the Red Fort. Here is the Taj Mahal seen from a distance with the reflecting pool in front. As luck would have it, the pool had been emptied for cleaning because President Sarkozy of France was coming for a visit, so we didn't see the reflection of the Taj Mahal in the pool.
photo.tags: travel india agra monument tomb architecture reflectingpool tajmahal

photo.title: At the Taj Mahal

photo.description: Not many buildings in the world can motivate tourists to wake up at five in the morning, skip breakfast and join a very long queue just for the privilege of seeing it. The Taj Mahal can.
photo.tags: tajmahal agra uttarpradesh worldheritagesite dawn sunrise india
photo.title: It's worth it

photo.title: Taj Mahal

photo.description: Time for a Change. I took a Polaroid Land Automatic 103 with me to India. I was so excited to take Polaroids of the Taj Mahal. An amazing place! The camera definitely attracted some attention 8-) What I didn't prepare for was what effect the heat would have on the Peel Apart Film. Sadly it had some effects on the gloss part of the film and it came apart and left dots on the originals, making them hard to scan. But I did my best in fixing as much as I could in post. Polaroid Land Automatic 103 Fuji FP-100C Gloss (Peel Apart Instant film)
photo.tags: 103 agra automatic fp100c fuji gloss india instant instantfilm peelapart polaroid polaroidland taj tajmahal
photo.title: The Taj Polaroid

photo.description: This is one of the Taj Mahal minaret towers. I took a Polaroid Land Automatic 103 with me to India. I was so excited to take Polaroids of the Taj Mahal. An amazing place! The camera definitely attracted some attention 8-) What I didn't prepare for was what effect the heat would have on the Peel Apart Film. Sadly it had some effects on the gloss part of the film and it came apart and left dots on the originals, making them hard to scan. But I did my best in fixing as much as I could in post. Polaroid Land Automatic 103 Fuji FP-100C Gloss (Peel Apart Instant film)
photo.tags: 103 agra automatic fp100c fuji gloss india instant instantfilm peelapart polaroid polaroidland taj tajmahal
photo.title: Minaret Tower...

photo.title: Taj Gateway

photo.description: "Taj Mahal" - The most beautiful grave in the world. According to the legend - "Shah Jahan" was planning to build an exact replica of it in black, at the other bank of the Yamuna river.
photo.tags: travel india agra taj mahal
photo.title: Agra - "Taj Mahal"
